title: Towards Logic-based Representations of Musical Harmony for Classification, Retrieval and Knowledge Discovery

author: Amelie Anglade, Centre for Digital Music, Department of Electronic Engineering, Queen Mary, University of London

segmentation: Good morning everybody.
Uh, so today I'd like to talk about the first part of my PhD project at the Center for Digital Music Queen Marina, City of London, which deals with logic based representation of musical harmony.
So the outline of my talk.
First, I will introduce the main machine learning concepts I will use as those I won't use.
Then the reasoning framework I plan to build, and I've started to build an its potential applications.
Um followed by the 1st experiments and some interesting results I got from these first experiments.
And finally, I would like to discuss the these result.
So first um, the main approach in music classification these days is the bag of friends or bag of features approach.
And the main idea behind this approach is that each class is represented by civil audio examples.
For each of these examples, the audio signal is getting too short, overlapping frames for each frame.
A feature vector is computed, and then these vectors are given to a statistical classifier which models the global distribution or the average value for each class.
And the features in this approach often deal with low level descriptors such as timbrell texture, rhythmic content, pitch count or combination of these three.
But this approach has several limitations.
For instance, contrary to the bag of friends approach, we know that the contribution of a musical event to the perceptual similarity is not proportional to its statistical importers.

An, for instance, very rare event in a song could be very representative of ajari or of a composer and using global distribution or even average values you cannot you miss those very rare but representative events.

And also the bag of features approaching knows the temporal dimension of the data an it has already been proven that if you looking at songs of the same jewelry or songs of the same composer, if you want to classify them into sub, subgenres, or sub classes, you will have problems because they are too statistically similar and you would need the temporal dimension to deal with these kind of.
Better.
So we believe that a logic based representation combined with a logical inference of musical concept can overcome this.
Limitations and biologically based representation I mean rules of these kinds.
